summary: nasopharyngeal swabs accurately predict the presence of viral infection. a signature of 3 mRNAs, CXCL10, IFIT2, and OASL, predicted respiratory virus detection with an accuracy of 97% (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.9–1.0) RNAseq The raw reads of RNAseq experiments were trimmed off sequencing adaptors and low-quality regions by btrim [15]. the counts of reads for each gene were based on Ensembl annotation (release 70) and differential expression analysis was done by DEseq2 [17]. Labels highlight transcripts examined as potential nasopharyngeal biomarkers of viral respiratory infection. RT-qPCR for biomarkers on RNA isolated from 68 NP swabs sent to the YNHH lab for respiratory virus testing. test for 3 host mRNAs and correlation with respiratory virus detection in 68 nasopharyngeal swabs (Study 1). Plots show mRNA levels for 68 samples relative to the mRNA level in resting human nasal epithelial cells (HNEC) each mRNA biomarker was scored positive if level was above the level observed in SLR14-stimulated HNEC. the YNHH virus panel does not include coronaviruses (CoV) we tested RNA from all patient samples using a previously described multiplex assay for 4 CoV genotypes. all 5 of the biomarker-positive, virus panel-negative samples were positive for CoV-OC43. the host response signature in Figure 2 is specific for viral infection. mRNAs triggered by RIG-I ligand encode chemokines. of the 8 chemokines tested, only CXCL9, CXCL10 and CXCL11 levels correlated with the presence of virus. patients were primarily older adults (72% of patients over the age of 50) and also included young children (15% of patients vs 6% in Study 1; Supplementary figures S1 and S3). CXCL10 and CXCL11 concentrations correlated highly with viral infection. nasopharyngeal swabs tested for respiratory viruses at Yale-New Haven hospital in 2016. NP swab CXCL10 or CXCL11 levels were measured using magnetic bead immunoassays. nucleic acids isolated from the viral transport medium were used to test for viruses not on the original test panel. Figure 5 shows the CXCL11 protein concentration in 219 samples. high CXCL11 levels correlated strongly with virus detection. low levels correlated with absence of virus, with intermediate levels indeterminate. possible rule in/rule out test for viral respiratory infection based on CXCL11 protein level. nasopharyngeal (NP) swabs measured 219 samples (Study 1 plus Study 2). black bars represent presence of virus. transcriptional changes were dominated by interferon-stimulated genes. these include mRNAs associated with respiratory virus infection. transcripts that encode secreted proteins were of particular interest because they could potentially serve as biomarkers of viral infection. a transcriptional signature based on 3 of the identified mRNAs could predict viral infection in nasopharyngeal swabs. RT-qPCR was performed for -actin and 3 mRNAs associated with the antiviral response. most patients were older adults with multiple comorbidities. mRNA levels were normalized to -actin mRNA in each sample. mRNA levels were normalized to the level of -actin mRNA in each sample. bars in virus column indicate samples that tested positive for respiratory virus by qPCR. the overall diagnostic accuracy of the mRNA biomarker test was 97% (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.9–1.0) and the positive predictive value was 100% (95% CI, 0.84–1.0). two of 68 samples represented false negatives (virus detected in the absence of ISG signature), including 1 rhinovirus (RV)+ and 1 human metapneumovirus (hMPV+ sample). levels of 8 chemokines identified in the RNAseq experiment. only CXCL9, CXCL10, and CXCL11 levels correlated with the presence of virus. levels of 8 chemokines were measured in viral transport medium associated with 65 NP swabs. samples were initially tested for the 9-virus panel and CoVs. results were compared to biomarker levels. three samples tested positive for parainfluenza virus type 4 (PIV4). virus positive samples, 43%) were positive for 10 distinct viruses. either CXCL11 or CXCL10 level was an excellent predictor of virus-positive and virus-negative status. the findings reveal that CXCL10 or CXCL11 concentration can predict infection with diverse viruses. about 1/3 of the samples (35%) fall into the indeterminate zone. a high degree of correlation between CXCL10 and CXCL11 protein concentrations. a high correlation of each biomarker with virus detection. mRNAs and proteins associated with NP swabs could be used to predict the detection of a respiratory virus in samples sent to our hospital laboratory for conventional virology testing. we chose possible biomarkers based on transcripts strongly induced by a virus-like stimulus in primary nasal epithelial cells. the consistent correlation of these chemokines with presence of diverse respiratory viruses in NP swabs suggests a particularly robust and conserved role for these chemokines in local antiviral defense of the upper respiratory tract. we defined an mRNA signature with very high diagnostic accuracy by combining the information from 3 biomarkers. in study 1, 16/68 (23.5%) of patients had COPD or asthma. 11 of these patients tested virus negative by the host mRNA biomarker signature. a pan-viral biomarker could be paired with an analogous biomarker of bacterial respiratory infection to distinguish among viral infection, bacterial infection, and viral/bacterial coinfection. biomarkers of the antiviral response are robustly detected using nasopharyngeal swabs, including protein biomarkers detected with immunoassay. even single biomarkers detected using this minimally invasive sample type offer high diagnostic accuracy. these results compel further study of using nasopharyngeal biomarkers for improving understanding of host/virus interactions. all authors have submitted the ICMJE Form for Disclosure of Potential Conflicts of Interest. conflicts that editors consider relevant to the content of the manuscript have been disclosed.
